name: Bill Johnson
content:
Good morning, dear friends…

I trust you are having a good weekend so far. It’s great, at least for us here in Ohio, to see the weather finally warm up. Yesterday was beautiful, and today is supposed to be nice as well. It’s as if hope for brighter days has finally burst forward.

Speaking of hope, have you ever needed a good dose of it? Have you ever felt disappointment so heavy that it felt as though you had been kicked in the stomach? Maybe it was the disappointment caused by a loved one’s rejection, the loss of a friendship, a job situation gone bad, or maybe even the death of a family member or someone close to you. I’m sure you have…we all have. It’s a natural part of life. Things don’t always go the way we want them to…or even the way we plan for them to go, in spite of how hard we worked. But, you know, there’s a reason for that. It’s because our Creator – the same Creator that grants us those unalienable rights of life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness – has a plan for us. And I can assure you, his plan is far superior to anything we can plan for ourselves…because he knows us, he knows our hearts desires, and he knows far better than we do what we need to be fulfilled and to become the men and women he created us to be. In fact, he tells us in his word that when faced with disappointment, we should relax, trust him, and turn to him for answers.

1 Thessalonians 5:16-18 – “Rejoice always, pray continually, give thanks in all circumstances; for this is God’s will for you in Christ Jesus.”

If you are facing disappointment today, my friend – whether it’s about a relationship, a problem on your job, maybe a problem at school, whatever it is – know that God loves you. He has a wonderful plan for you, and he will fulfill that plan in you in his time and in ways that only he could. Have a blessed day!

name: Jeff Duncan
content:
National Police Week allows us the opportunity to recognize and celebrate the accomplishments of law enforcement officers across our great country.

And I’m proud to cosponsor the following bills filed this week to assist law enforcement officers as they do their life-saving work in communities everywhere. These bills send a strong message of support for the rule of law and those who maintain law and order.

H.R.3080 - Congressman Don Bacon's Back the Blue Act will:

• Create a new federal crime for killing, attempting to kill, or conspiring to kill a federal judge, federal law enforcement officer, or federally funded public safety officer
• Create a new federal crime for assaulting a federally funded law enforcement officer, with escalating penalties, including mandatory minimums, based on the extent of any injury and the use of a dangerous weapon
• Create a new federal crime for interstate flight from justice to avoid prosecution for killing, attempting to kill, or conspiring to kill a federal judge, federal law enforcement officer, or federally funded public safety officer
• Create a specific aggravating factor for federal death penalty prosecutions
• Expand self-defense and Second Amendment rights for law enforcement officers
• Open grant funding to strengthen relationships between police and communities

H.R. 3079 - Congressman John Rutherford’s Protect and Serve Act of 2021 will:

• Create enhanced penalties for anyone who targets law enforcement officers and purposefully harms them. This applies to attacks on any federal officer, or state or local officer if the attacker or officer crosses state lines, uses a channel of interstate commerce, uses a firearm or weapon that traveled in interstate commerce, or if the act effects interstate or foreign commerce
• Create a penalty of up to 10 years imprisonment for someone who attacks and injures an officer and a penalty of life in prison for someone who kills or kidnaps an officer

H.R. 3217 - Representative Matt Rosendale’s Lawless Cities Accountability Act of 2021 will:

• Bar funding to a jurisdiction that the Attorney General determines is a “lawless jurisdiction,” which is a State or political subdivision of a State that:
• Forbids a law enforcement agency from intervening to restore order amid widespread or sustained violence or destruction
• Withdraws law enforcement protection from a geographical area or structure that law enforcement officers are lawfully entitled to access
• Disempowers or defunds law enforcement agencies
• Refuses to accept an offer of law enforcement assistance from the Federal Government amid widespread violence or destruction

This week, I reintroduced the "Buyback Our Safety Act," a bill to support local gun buyback initiatives.

Unwanted firearms in the home can lead to unintended tragedies. Gun buyback programs help prevent gun-related accidents at home, including by children, and reduce the chance of these guns ending up in the wrong hands.
